awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of an advanced imaging system at a primarily undergraduate institution to promote research, teaching, and science outreach
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to West Chester University of Pennsylvania to support the acquisition of a confocal imaging and total internal reflection microscopy (TIRF) system. This imaging system will enable researchers at West Chester University and other regional institutions to perform cutting-edge research, provide transformative undergraduate research experiences, and promote STEM career advancement for trainees. The new system will ensure that faculty can expand their research focus, publish in high quality journals, and remain competitive for external funding opportunities. Importantly, the PIs on this grant are committed to training undergraduates in confocal/TIRF microscopy to ensure their students remain competitive in academic and professional fields. The new microscope will be integrated into independent undergraduate research projects, Biology or Physics lab courses, and outreach programs that focus on engaging underrepresented groups in the sciences.
 
Research projects enabled by the new confocal system include: (1) using in vivo approaches to study how folic acid, an essential vitamin, affects embryonic development, (2) biophysical in vitro studies on the folding of a novel nucleic acid structural motif in the presence and absence of molecular crowding, (3) discovering novel mechanisms of mitochondrial dynamics and cell adhesion in single-celled parasites, and (4) using ex vivo explant cultures to examine cell sorting behavior and changes in cell-cell adhesion during early embryonic development in Xenopus laevis. The imaging system will enhance faculty research capabilities, serve as a catalyst for future initiatives, and promote interdisciplinary and cross-institutional research among its broad user base. Data and analyses from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, presented at scientific meetings, and used in both educational and public outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to purchase and install a spinning disk confocal microscopy system with enhanced capabilities for TIRF and single-molecule imaging to support research, teaching, and outreach activities at West Chester University of Pennsylvania (WCU). West Chester University is a public, primarily undergraduate institution about 40 miles outside of Philadelphia, serving 17,527 undergraduate students of which approximately 23% receive Pell grants, and approximately 30% are first generation college students. Acquisition of this system has greatly improved our imaging resources as this is the only microscope on the campus capable of confocal imaging or TIRF microscopy.


The microscopy system funded by this grant is part of the core equipment at WCU?s Center for Microanalysis and Imaging Research and Training (CMIRT), greatly improving the impact of this center and ability for future researchers to perform experimentation that relies on confocal and/or TIRF capabilities. Since acquisition of the microscope, independent research students, both undergraduate and graduate have used the microscopy system to study cell fate decisions and cell migrations using the nematode C. elegans as a model system. We believe research studies relying on this microscopy system will become an integral part of faculty research and has already helped recruit faculty for both the new Bioengineering Program and the Biology Department. WCU has a history of long-term stewardship of NSF funded instrumentation decades beyond the funding period. This long impact is evidenced by more than 95% of publications utilizing CMIRT instruments occurring more than three years after the instrument was acquired and thus, we are excited about the opportunities for publications as the research base for the instrument grows.


Since the acquisition of the microscope, confocal microscopy has consistently been incorporated into two upper-division labs: Cell and Molecular Biology (12-24 students/semester) and Developmental Biology (20-24 students/year) in which students learn about confocal microscopy, mount specimens for imaging, and with the instructor, acquire images of their specimen. The students are then able to use these images to perform quantification and analysis. Integrating learning activities using this microscopy system has been a valuable addition to our upper division labs as it affords more educational and career readiness opportunities. Having the ability to incorporate confocal microscopy directly into our courses is also important from an equity perspective. Because these classes are either required in major concentrations or are popular electives, more students can experience confocal microscopy then if the only other opportunities were available in research labs. We believe providing research experiences in the classroom reaches a greater number of students and provides more equal opportunities for students being competitive candidates when applying to post-graduate research positions. In addition to these upper-level courses, a cohort of WCU first year undergraduate students from the NSF funded S-STEM scholarship program were introduced to the microscopy system as part of the summer STEMersion camp.

The broader impacts of obtaining the microscopy system continue to be realized, primarily through its involvement in WCU's Super Science Saturday event. Super Science Saturday is an annual event in which approximately 100 middle school and high school students from local schools visit WCU and attend various STEM related activities, including gaining exposure to this state-of-the-art microscopy. We will continue to incorporate use of the microscope to future outreach events hosted at WCU with goals to connect more directly with local high schools to bring students to campus. Taken together, obtaining this microscopy system has greatly enhanced WCU's research, educational and outreach capabilities, and we strongly believe that our place of serving large populations of first-generation students will provide an outside impact in expanding the STEM workforce throughout the future life of this equipment.

Modified by: Jessica Sullivan-Brown
